metadata.case_name: Sawatram Ramprasad Mills Co., Ltd., Akola v. Two Workmen

facts.text: Respondents are two workmen of the Mills claiming compensation for lay off from March 5, 1960 to October 22, 1960.
Proceedings commenced by application to the Second Labour Court, Bombay under s. 33C(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Mills objected that Second Labour Court had no jurisdiction as dispute fell under C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947, and s. 33C application incompetent.
Second Labour Court held against the Mills on both grounds.
Mills applied to Bombay High Court (Nagpur Bench) under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution; application dismissed on August 25, 1962.
Similar applications by other workmen heard together on preliminary point.
Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 applied to Textile Industry; brought into force April 1, 1947.

C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 (Act 23 of 1947) came into force June 2, 1947 (first section), remaining sections November 20, 1947 except Textile Industry; applicable to Textile from March 1, 1951.
Industrial Disputes Act amended in 1953 adding definitions of 'lay-off' and 'retrenchment', and Chapter V-A (Lay Off and Retrenchment).
Section 25C gives right to compensation for lay-off under conditions.
Section 25J: Chapter V-A has effect notwithstanding inconsistent laws; rights re lay-off determined under this Chapter.
Industrial Disputes Act amended in 1956 inserting s. 33C for recovery of money due under Chapter V-A.
Powers under s. 33C delegated to Second Labour Court, Bombay.
Section 31 of 1956 Amending Act: Does not affect State Acts re settlement/adjudication except as amended.
Dates of lay-off known; qualification from muster rolls; simple arithmetical calculation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Second Labour Court, Bombay had jurisdiction or the dispute falls under C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947.
Whether application under s. 33C of Industrial Disputes Act competent for lay-off compensation, or requires predetermined sum without calculation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dispute to be tried under C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, not Central Industrial Disputes Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 31 of 1956 Amendment Act; opening part of s. 25J; Preamble of C.P. Berar Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if Central Act applies, calculation of amount cannot be made under s. 33C as it requires proceedings other than those contemplated.
Claim for lay-off not a claim for money due as calculations have to be made before amount found.

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to compensation for lay-off under Chapter V-A via s. 33C(1).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S. 33C Industrial Disputes Act; Chapter V-A

court_reasoning.text: Compensation for lay-off determined only under Chapter V-A per s. 25J(2); workmen entitled under s. 33C(1) to approach Labour Court for money due under Chapter V-A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: C.P. Berar Act contains no provision for lay-off compensation or recovery.

court_reasoning.text: S. 31 no application as s. 33C enables claim under Chapter V-A; C.P. Berar Act saved subject to Chapter V-A for lay-off.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lay-off and compensation only in Central Act Chapter V-A.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Court can compute amount under s. 33C(2); not essential claim be for predetermined sum; simple calculation from muster rolls permitted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rejected argument per Kays Construction; Labour Court decides if lay-off occurred.

holdings.text: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (Chapter V-A and s. 33C) applies; C.P. Berar Act does not oust it for lay-off compensation.
S. 33C permits computation of lay-off compensation by Labour Court even if not predetermined sum.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kays Construction Co. (P) Ltd. v. State of U.P. Ors
precedents_cited.relevance: Rejected argument that s. 33C(1) requires predetermined sum; computation permitted.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs lay-off compensation rights, computation and recovery; overrides inconsistent state laws for lay-off/retrenchment.

statutes_cited.name: C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 (Act 23 of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Does not apply to lay-off compensation; saved by s. 31/25J but subject to Central Act Chapter V-A.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Bombay High Court judgment dismissed; Second Labour Court has jurisdiction under s. 33C for lay-off compensation claim.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; respondents' claim proceeds.

key_quotes.text: "The provisions of this Chapter shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any law including standing orders..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: S. 25J establishes supremacy of Chapter V-A for lay-off.

key_quotes.text: "compensation for lay off can only be determined under Chapter V-A of the Industrial Disputes Act. This follows from s. 25J(2)"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is not essential that the claim... must always be for a predetermined sum."
key_quotes.speaker: court
